author: sky.cactus
content: It is much easier to create a new chain with n second block times than to change an existing chain to n second block times.  Certainly not impossible, but a lot of external tools assume 12 seconds.  There is not an RPC to ask for current block time as far as I know, so people hard coded to make it work.  Perhaps the lesson to learn here is that if you don't want people hard coding a value, make sure there is an RPC for it at launch.

author: sky.cactus
content: When we talk about block time changes, is it under the assumption that gas per second is disconnected from block time?  I would like to see that disconnect happen in parralel or before a block time change.  I would feel bad if a gas per second increase was "snuck" in via block time changes rather than being debated on its own merits.  I don't think people are trying to do that on purpose, but I think it will look like that to an outside observer if we don't disconnect first.

author: ajsutton

Block time isn‚Äôt actually fixed at 12 seconds today (there can be empty slots) and Ethereum‚Äôs history of PoW means it originally had variable block times.
So while there may be some surprises I wouldn‚Äôt expect tooling to be a major issue when changing block times.
Having consensus clients be able to change timings at a particular slot will be much more interesting to implement - very doable but will take a fair bit of effort to make schedulers more dynamic and track down everywhere things need to handle the switch.

author: cskiraly
content:
The thing  about slot time is that we have quite some safety margin in there in each part. IMHO we should first understand the role and utility of these safety margins before making statements about reducing the times.

Looking at avarages, you don't see the role of these safety margins. Although looking at statistics brings you closer, but it is not just data based analysis, it is really understanding the effect of not having those safety margins.
What happens if we increase the chances of having a consecutive series of "timeouts"? What happens if we increase the changes of a making geographic devides in the overlay? 

Having said that, I'm convinced we can make reductions.

author: cskiraly
content: I would like to start doing tests where we intentionally constrain network resources to understand some of these dynamics.

author: cskiraly
content: This, in some sense, would be the opposite of bloatnet and similar efforts, where we are bumping params while keep the network unconstrained. The focus here would be on constraining network first, mapping out the bottlenecks, and only then start playing with scaling other params.

author: .piersy
content:
Hi all ‚Äî Celo team member hereüëã
We‚Äôd like to open a conversation around the upcoming sunset of the Holesky testnet and its impact on L2s.

As many rollups and L2s continue to mature, Holesky has become an important part of the testing infrastructure ‚Äî particularly for those using it as the L1 testnet. With Holesky scheduled to sunset on September 30, 2025, we wanted to raise a potential path forward for discussion.

Using Celo as one example: we recently transitioned to an Ethereum L2 architecture, and both our testnets currently depend on Holesky. Based on the current timeline, we‚Äôd need to migrate to Sepolia in the short term ‚Äî only to migrate again when Sepolia is deprecated a year later. This creates added overhead and complexity not just for us, but likely for others in a similar position.

To simplify testnet maintenance, we‚Äôd like to propose extending Holesky‚Äôs lifespan. This would allow projects to align directly with Sepolia‚Äôs successor, while also ensuring sufficient overlap for a smooth migration.

We‚Äôd love to hear what others think ‚Äî especially teams that are also building on or relying on Holesky today. Would an extension be helpful? Are there alternative paths we should be considering?

We‚Äôre also curious whether the Ethereum Foundation and broader community would be open to this idea. And if not, what guidance you might have for teams navigating the transition.

Looking forward to hearing your thoughts ‚Äî thanks for the discussion

author: jochembrouwer
content:
Hey all, I could sadly not join ACD but am relistening now. For EIP-7825 (gas limit tx cap) we could also consider limiting to `2^16-1 = 16_777_215`, (instead of 30M) this would make the gas limit cap fit within a `bytes2` / `uint16` thus a slight benefit to quickly reject it at txpool level. Downside is that current full-block txs are invalid (plus that this indirectly limits the practical max contract size to deploy due to calldata+code deposit gas cost)

See https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/eip-7825-transaction-gas-limit-cap/21848/3?u=jochem-brouwer
